data.title: Is Sysmex (TSE:6869) Now Fairly Priced After A 45% One Year Share Price Slide?
data.description:
• If you are wondering whether Sysmex shares are now priced attractively or still have further to fall, this article walks through what the current share price might be implying about the company's value.
  • The stock last closed at ¬•1,467, after a 9.6% move over the past 7 days, a modest 0.3% return over 30 days, and longer term returns of a 4.4% decline year to date, a 44.9% decline over 1 year, a 45.0% decline over 3 years, and a 58.1% decline over 5 years.
  • Recent coverage around Sysmex has focused on its position in the healthcare sector and how investors are reassessing companies in this space, especially those with established products and global reach. This backdrop helps frame why the share price has shifted recently and why some investors are rechecking their assumptions about what a fair price looks like today.
  • On our valuation checks, Sysmex currently scores 3 out of 6, meaning it screens as undervalued on half of the metrics we track. Next, we will look at what different valuation methods say about that score, before finishing with a more complete way to think about value that ties all of these pieces together.

Find out why Sysmex's -44.9% return over the last year is lagging behind its peers.

Approach 1: Sysmex Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis

A Discounted Cash Flow, or DCF, model takes estimates of the cash a company may generate in future years and discounts those amounts back into today‚Äôs money to arrive at an estimated intrinsic value per share.

For Sysmex, the model used is a 2 Stage Free Cash Flow to Equity approach, based on cash flow projections in ¬•. The latest twelve month free cash flow is ¬•27,423.60 million. Analyst estimates and subsequent extrapolations point to projected free cash flow of ¬•50,425.75 million by the year ending March 2030, with a series of annual projections between now and 2035 that Simply Wall St has discounted back to today.

When all of those projected cash flows are added and discounted, the model arrives at an estimated fair value of ¬•1,567.57 per share. Compared with the recent market price of ¬•1,467, the DCF output implies Sysmex trades at about a 6.4% discount to this estimate, which places it in the ‚Äúroughly in line‚Äù bucket rather than looking extremely cheap or expensive.

Result: ABOUT RIGHT

Sysmex is fairly valued according to our Discounted Cash Flow (DCF), but this can change at a moment's notice. Track the value in your watchlist or portfolio and be alerted on when to act.

Head to the Valuation section of our Company Report for more details on how we arrive at this Fair Value for Sysmex.

Approach 2: Sysmex Price vs Earnings

P/E is a useful way to think about valuation for profitable companies because it directly links what you pay for each share to the earnings that support that share. When investors expect stronger growth or see lower risk, they are usually willing to accept a higher P/E, while slower growth or higher risk tends to justify a lower P/E.

Sysmex currently trades on a P/E of 20.4x. That is close to the Medical Equipment industry average of 15.5x and very similar to the peer average of 20.5x, so on simple comparisons the stock looks roughly in line with similar names rather than clearly cheap or expensive.

Simply Wall St‚Äôs Fair Ratio is a proprietary estimate of what P/E might make sense for Sysmex given its earnings growth profile, industry, profit margins, market cap and risk factors. This is more tailored than a straight peer or industry comparison because those benchmarks do not adjust for company specific strengths or weaknesses. For Sysmex, the Fair Ratio is 26.6x, which is higher than the current 20.4x P/E, suggesting the shares trade below this estimate of fair value.

Result: UNDERVALUED

The Excess Returns model looks at how much profit a company can earn above its cost of equity and then capitalizes those surplus returns into an estimated fair value per share.

For Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings, the model used is a 2 Stage Free Cash Flow to Equity approach. On a last twelve months basis, the company reported free cash flow of a $448.9 million loss, so the valuation leans heavily on future projections rather than recent cash generation.

The projections indicate free cash flow turning positive and reaching $1,233 million in 2028, with further annual figures out to 2035 derived from analyst inputs and extrapolations by Simply Wall St. These ten-year free cash flow estimates, all in dollars, are then discounted back using the DCF framework.

data.title: Principal Financial Group Adds Flexible Shelf Capacity For Future Funding Choices
data.description:
• Principal Financial Group (NasdaqGS:PFG) has filed a comprehensive shelf registration statement.
  • The filing covers multiple types of securities, including equity and debt instruments.
  • The shelf registration allows the company to raise capital in the future in amounts and at times it selects.

Principal Financial Group, a diversified financial services company focused on retirement, asset management, and insurance solutions, now has an additional tool it can use when it chooses to access capital markets. For investors, a shelf registration like this often sits in the background until management decides conditions are suitable to issue securities. It does not commit the company to raise funds, but it sets up the framework to do so efficiently.

This filing indicates that management is seeking flexibility to respond if funding needs, acquisition opportunities, or regulatory capital requirements arise. The key thing to monitor is how, when, and in what form NasdaqGS:PFG eventually uses this capacity, because equity, debt, or hybrid offerings can affect the risk profile and potential returns in different ways.

Stay updated on the most important news stories for Principal Financial Group by adding it to your watchlist or portfolio. Alternatively, explore our Community to discover new perspectives on Principal Financial Group.

We've flagged 0 risks for Principal Financial Group. See which could impact your investment.

This universal shelf gives Principal Financial Group a ready made menu of funding options, from common and preferred equity to debt, warrants, and bundled purchase units. For a diversified insurer and asset manager, that kind of flexibility can matter when you think about regulatory capital, potential acquisitions, or refinancing existing obligations. The filing itself does not change earnings or cash flows today, but it can influence how management funds future growth or supports shareholder returns such as dividends and buybacks.

Advertisement

How This Fits Into The Principal Financial Group Narrative

  • The ability to issue a mix of securities could support the existing focus on retirement and global asset management if management chooses to fund organic growth, technology, or bolt on deals that build scale in those areas.
  • If equity or equity linked securities are issued, that could run against the narrative of capital strength and cash returns by introducing dilution, especially when analysts already hold mostly neutral views.
  • The shelf increases optionality around future M&A or balance sheet moves, which is not fully captured in the existing discussion that focuses more on margins, flows, and pricing rather than funding structure.

  • ‚ö†Ô∏è If new debt securities are issued on less favorable terms, interest costs could pressure margins in a sector where peers like MetLife and Prudential also compete for capital.
  • üéÅ A pre cleared shelf can let Principal move quickly if attractive acquisition or partnership opportunities appear in retirement or asset management, without long lead times.
  • üéÅ Flexible capital tools give management more ways to balance growth investments, dividends, and buybacks, which may appeal to income focused investors if used conservatively.

What To Watch Going Forward

From here, keep an eye on whether Principal starts to issue any securities off this shelf, in what size, and for what stated purpose. The mix between equity and debt will matter for earnings per share, leverage and dividend capacity, especially given recent analyst caution on upside potential. data.description:

Approach 1: CorMedix Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis

A Discounted Cash Flow, or DCF, model takes estimates of the cash a company might generate in the future and discounts those back to today, aiming to arrive at an intrinsic value per share based on those projected cash flows.

For CorMedix, the model used is a 2 Stage Free Cash Flow to Equity approach, working with recent Free Cash Flow of about $73.9 million. Analysts provide specific Free Cash Flow estimates for the coming years, and Simply Wall St then extrapolates further to build a 10 year path. On this basis, projected Free Cash Flow reaches $209.8 million in 2030, with additional years beyond that also modeled in millions of US dollars.

When all those future cash flows are discounted back to today, the DCF model produces an estimated intrinsic value of about $91.95 per share. Compared to the recent share price of US$7.35, this suggests the stock is 92.0% undervalued according to this method.

Result: UNDERVALUED

Our Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) analysis suggests CorMedix is undervalued by 92.0%. Track this in your watchlist or portfolio, or discover 54 more high quality undervalued stocks.

Head to the Valuation section of our Company Report for more details on how we arrive at this Fair Value for CorMedix.

Approach 2: CorMedix Price vs Earnings

For a company that has positive earnings, the P/E ratio is a straightforward way to think about what you are paying for each dollar of profit. It helps you compare CorMedix with other businesses that also generate earnings in the same sector.

A higher or lower P/E often reflects what the market expects for future growth and how risky those earnings might be. Higher expected growth and lower perceived risk can support a higher ‚Äúnormal‚Äù P/E, while lower growth expectations or higher risk can justify a lower one.

CorMedix currently trades on a P/E of 3.56x. That is below the Pharmaceuticals industry average of 19.89x and below the peer average of 9.43x. Simply Wall St also calculates a ‚ÄúFair Ratio‚Äù for CorMedix of 15.70x, which is an estimate of what the P/E might be given factors such as its earnings profile, industry, profit margins, market cap and specific risks.

This Fair Ratio aims to be more tailored than a simple comparison with peers or the industry because it adjusts for growth characteristics, risk and profitability instead of assuming all companies deserve the same multiple. When you compare CorMedix‚Äôs current P/E of 3.56x with the Fair Ratio of 15.70x, the shares screen as undervalued on this metric.

Approach 1: National Energy Services Reunited Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis

A Discounted Cash Flow, or DCF, model takes the cash that a company is expected to generate in the future and discounts it back to today to estimate what the entire business could be worth now.

For National Energy Services Reunited, the latest twelve month Free Cash Flow is about $153.0 million. The model used here is a 2 Stage Free Cash Flow to Equity approach, which first applies analyst forecasts and then extends those cash flows further out using additional assumptions by Simply Wall St.

The projections used in the model include Free Cash Flow of $154.6 million in 2026 and $219.0 million in 2028, with further years out to 2035 based on extrapolated estimates, all in $. When these projected cash flows are discounted back to today, the DCF model arrives at an estimated intrinsic value of about $58.38 per share.

Compared with the recent share price of $25.14, this DCF estimate suggests a difference of around 56.9% between the modelled intrinsic value and the current market price.

Approach 2: National Energy Services Reunited Price vs Earnings

For a profitable company, the P/E ratio is a straightforward way to see how much you are paying for each dollar of earnings. This makes it a useful cross check alongside a DCF model. What counts as a ‚Äúnormal‚Äù P/E depends on what the market expects for future earnings growth and how risky those earnings are, with higher expected growth or lower perceived risk usually supporting a higher multiple.

National Energy Services Reunited currently trades on a P/E of about 49.6x. That sits above both the Energy Services industry average of roughly 26.6x and the peer group average of about 32.7x. This suggests the market is applying a richer multiple than these broad comparison points.
